title: 'Traumatised' passengers of British Airways plane that caught fire on US runway to sue
text:
'Traumatised' passengers of British Airways plane that caught fire on US runway to sue Last updated 10:30, September 24 2015 SYDNEY MORNING HERALD 
More than 150 people are evacuated when a British Airways plane catches fire on the runway of McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas. 
Airline passengers in the US are seeking legal action citing physical and emotional trauma after they plane they were aboard caught fire on a runway in Las Vegas. 
On September 8, a British Airways airplane was accelerating for takeoff when it caught fire on the runway at Las Vegas' McCarran International Airport, forcing the pilot to hit the brakes. The blaze sent smoke pouring from an engine and led passengers and crew to flee down emergency slides. The Boeing 777-200 was leaving for a 10-hour flight to London with 157 passengers aboard. 
Passengers and crew on the flight were photographed running from the burning plane. The Daily Mail reported that the incident left passengers with physical injuries and psychological trauma. Twitter 
An engine on a London-bound British Airways jet caught fire while the plane was preparing to take off from Las Vegas. 
Steve Bingham, one of the passengers on board, said he has been prescribed medication to help him cope with "regular flashbacks". 
Bingham, from Northern Ireland, said he also suffered an arm injury and smoke inhalation as the plane was evacuated. 
He, and other people who were aboard the plane, are seeking legal action to sue for compensation. Just landed in Vegas to see this...plane on fire on the Tarmac...people still onboard and running off! pic.twitter.com/ul10hFFw9j — David L. Somers (@DL_Somers) September 8, 2015 
Bingham told of his ordeal in a statement: "The plane accelerated for take-off, then there was a loud bang and jolt followed by an abrupt stop. "At that point, I thought the plane was going to tip on its side or crash. "Many people were screaming, with some then shouting about fire. Then I saw thick black smoke from the windows on both sides of the aircraft, but the cabin crew were still telling us to stay seated at that point. Seconds later, the pilot ordered the evacuation. "Once out of the plane, the staff were screaming at us to run away. I started to run and looked back towards the plane to see that it was on fire with flames reaching twice the height of the aircraft. "All I could think was that if it reaches the fuel tanks and explodes we will be killed." 
Bingham said he is still suffering from the incident and has regular flashbacks, adding: 'You simply never expect something like this to happen. I am continuing to suffer from the effects of what happened, but I know we are all incredibly lucky not to have been more seriously injured.' 
A spokesman for Irwin Mitchell, a UK law firm, said it was acting for 40 passengers from Britain and Ireland who were on board the flight. The spokesman said: "There are a number of potential defendants but our investigation into who is ultimately liable for this incident is ongoing." An apology letter from BA. It's 9.45pm in Las Vegas and we have just heard from a beleaguered tour guide. pic.twitter.com/eaLvk8l0Ws — Jacob Steinberg (@JacobSteinberg) September 9, 2015 
A British Airways spokeswoman said the airline cannot discuss claims about the evacuation as it will form part of the National Transportation Safety Board investigation into the incident.
